pros:
-Fast paced environment with solid leadership that is open to listening to ideas no matter your level in the company
-True collaborative environment
-Senior leadership is incredibly welcoming and made me feel apart of the team from day 1
- Co-workers are eager to answer questions and help you in any way they can
-Fun perks and an understanding of work-life balance
-Although it's a growing company, there is a lot of importance placed on staying true to the mission, values, and culture
cons: - No 401K matching, but other than that I haven't found any
advice_to_mgmt: This is the best company culture I've ever been apart of. Keep doing what you're doing by trusting your employees and investing in us - can't wait to see what the future holds.

review_title: Couldn't be happier, Found my place
pros:
surrounded by smart, driven people who are passionate about their jobs
free lunch
Work from home Wednesdays
travel quarterly for team offsite
cons: Not AS flexible on working from home, but we do work from home once a week. So give and take. each of our teams seem to work in silos, so would be great to make sure everyone is connected and on the same page so we can grow together.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire more senior folks who have "been there and done that" so teams have strong, strategic guidance and can be better overall

pros: Great people. Solid team. Cares about employees. Work from home Wednesdays for the entire company. Commute stipends. New 10k Fertility and Adoption benefits. Growing client base with deep pockets. Fun Offsites throughout the US to connect with remote employees.
cons: None that I can think of.
advice_to_mgmt: As we scale, keep hiring strong leaders and trust them to do the work.

pros:
- the incredible amount of trust given to us by the CEO
- working in a real industry with real problems (and real opportunities)
- working with some of the nicest, smartest people I've ever met
cons: - too many company off-sites, difficult for those of us with families
advice_to_mgmt:
- keep trusting the people you've hired to do their job
- give new employees a chance to thrive and shine

review_title: Great people, decent culture, struggling leadership
pros:
- Overall a fun place to work. Great people who are competent, know how to get things done, and know the importance of having a good time.
- An individual's success/enjoyment may depend on their team's style. The overall culture is appealing. But, if you're interviewing, try to understand how your team approaches its process and internal management. What are the expectations? How will they support your growth?
- The perks are legitimate, but anyone can find something they don't care for or wish could be better. We all have our share of suggestions. Many of them seem to be taken into consideration. Some are not.
- A very promising business model, and the company proves its value quarter after quarter.
cons:
- Number one is lack of trained management/leadership. High-growth company hadn't figured out the gravity of training leaders well.
- Related, no clear path for growth/advancement.
- Also related, though the culture is positively tangible, it can seem like numbers/success come before people. Sometimes perks act like a pacifier, but developing employees takes dedicated, hard work.
- Secondly, expectations for individuals are unclear.

All of this revolves around a lack of self-awareness among management. It's one thing to put your head down and get the work done. Having fun here and there is great. But when leadership doesn't learn how to truly put people first, employees burn out.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Focus on developing good managers, who can then develop good employees.
- Don't overly rely on perks or "culture." Rather, treat employees like career-minded adults.

review_title: Fun place to work with a great mission, but leadership needs help
pros:
- Amazing mission that employees are proud to support
- Fun culture and great, hard-working people
cons:
- Lack of self-awareness and general awareness among management and the illusion of room for growth isn't fair to dedicated employees who take the time to provide feedback that is seemingly never considered.

- Employees can go years without a promotion or a change in title and expectations are unclear.
advice_to_mgmt: Instead of rushing to hire new managers who have no context of the company or past projects, look inward and lean on the experience and loyalty of capable veteran employees who are looking for growth.

pros:
The leadership is second to none, and everything follows from leadership. I've been in the industry for 15+ years and I've never seen such genuine, smart, capable, successful and humble senior management. Their effect on the rest of the company is tangible (or should I say "Tangney-ible"; yes, that just happened). No task or person is too small, it's very rare and refreshing.
Other than that, it's just a joy to get up and be able to work here every day. My tasks are meaningful, we have all the tools we need to get things done efficiently, and there's no time wasted in meetings or otherwise.
The only downside is that it will be hard to top this. Even if someone offered me a stupid amount of money, I'd probably pass. You can't buy being happy at your job, and feeling like you're part of a big family that all truly care about one another.
cons: Absolutely none. At this company, we don't wait to solve problems, we bring them up as they happen, and deal with them.

review_title: A true pearl in a sea of Startups
pros:
Doximity has truly perfected the semi-remote office environment. I am one of many employees (from around the world) that works remotely, and I must say, this has been one of the most pleasant experiences; and it may just be a testament to the quality of people that work here, but my working hours (and well-being) are sincerely respected by every single person. There are four off-sites a year where everyone gets together to relax and reflect on our accomplishments and establish goals; and these are a real treat after months of remote work where you don't get face-time with the team.

From an engineering point of view, there is never a dull moment. At this point, the entire process is a well-oiled machine. Teams are broken into small groups of no more than 10, work is broken up reasonably (yet still challenging) into quarters, and the technology stack continues to grow in some bleeding-edge stuff. There is a yearly stipend to learn new things and attend conferences to keep your brain juices flowing. The best thing I find about working here is the personal consideration of my growth. If I want to lead a team, kick off new tech, better our process, or just take it easy for a bit, my voice is heard and offered the opportunity.

Financially, salary is competitive, the medical benefits are impressive, yearly bonus, potential spot-bonuses from co-workers, and a stake in an incredible company with some nice legs.
cons: At times, goals can be set at a pretty high bar that can lead to some stressful end-of-quarter rushes.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue hiring great people and supporting a remote-working mentality. Consider exploring more open-source contributions.

review_title: Great environment to move fast and grow
pros:
* Lots of opportunities to learn and grow.
* Chance to build software to improve quality of care.
* Ability to make a difference and drive improvement with original ideas.
* Very little red-tape, which allows for solutions to make their way out the door and into the hands of users quickly.
* Motivated and caring team.
cons: * Benefits & pay could be better, like matching 401k
advice_to_mgmt: It is important we all recognize our own shortcomings and allow qualified and experienced people address specific company needs. There is no shortage of talent and commitment, almost everywhere you look.

pros: Great teamwork, through code review process, growth opportunities, rapid growth, friendly environment, great female leaders
cons: limited sick leave. I wish I can say more about it ..

pros:
- The goals for the company, each team and every individual are so clear, everyone is paddling in the same direction and because of this, we get a tremendous amount of work done.

- A large portion of the company is remote and Dox has done a great job making sure everyone feels connected and part of the team.

- If you work hard there are opportunities for growth
cons: Typical growing pains for a company of our size

pros:
Great team full of smart, friendly, hard-working people.
Amazing work environment I'm still excited to go to every day.
cons: Honestly there are not many. Management has been great in my experience, which is a refreshing rarity. Offsites can get exhausting after a while, but that's hardly something to complain about. Company is growing, so some departments have more mature processes than others.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on recognizing and rewarding good work and ideas and leading the company in the right direction!

pros: Fun team environment, great perks
cons: Some employees undervalued, management not always up-front
advice_to_mgmt: n/a

review_title: Highly collaborative teams with great culture!
pros:
- Great mission and product
- Even greater engineering Team
- Work from home Wednesday
- Free lunch & snack
- Cool company rooftop bar
- Option for remote for some positions
- Company off-sites to all the cool places
cons: - Since the company isn't large yet, there might be limited opportunity for career growth

pros: Learn a lot and puts you on track to be a great sales director
cons: I don't have any cons!

review_title: Horrible Work Culture and Unreasonable Expectations
pros: The people seem nice at first but then you realize it's a gossip-machine and people are out to get you. They are all fake to your face and then talk badly behind your back, and the even though you think they are your friend, they end up screwing you over.
cons: There are too many to list - fake people, backstabbers, unrealistic, inhumane expectations, really low morale and anal-retentive leadership, no work/life balance, meager snacks.
advice_to_mgmt: Learn to LISTEN to your employees when they are trying to tell you something and don't be so stubborn and only do what you think is best. It's supposed to be a collaborative work environment, or so you boast, but does not live up to expectations = LIE.

pros:
Great culture
Really smart people who care
Amazingly flat considering how much the company has grown. Everyone has a chance to contribute and management listens
CEO is excellent because he listens to others and doesn't dictate from the top down. Knows that he doesn't always have the best idea
HQ benefits are fantastic with catered lunch, snacks, etc. And a rooftop deck too boot!
cons: Growing pretty quickly so roles are getting necessarily more confined but that is to be expected
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on doing what you are doing

review_title: Did you work at Epocrates? If not, enjoy your short time here
pros: Great benefits compared to what most other companies are offering
cons: There is no "carrot" here, only "stick". Unreachable revenue expectations and, unless you are "in" because you worked with the founder at his previous company (look how well they're doing!) there is no hope for you. Constant stress with the only goal being to "make the number", morality be dammed.
advice_to_mgmt: Read the story about Outcomes Health in the WSJ. It won't be long before there is a similar one about Dox.

review_title: great people doing the work....self-absorbed ego-maniacs (pretending not to be) running the place
pros: office space is cool?
cons: watch the comp plans and make sure the company pays what they have agreed to...and when it is due.
advice_to_mgmt: get a grip management team, you're not that great or uber entrepreneurs. However, kudos on borrowing the model from LinkedIn and then getting good folks to pull it off on a daily basis.

pros: Remote options, and great healthcare.
cons: One-on-one pair programming is difficult as a remote.

pros:
Vision – Healthcare is ripe for improvement and it’s inspiring to work for a company that is tackling real problems. The CEO is a visionary and gracefully walks the fine line of being a leader without micromanaging.

Ownership – Everyone has a big part in the company’s success. At our weekly all hands meetings you hear about work that’s being done. It gives us an appreciation of the different pieces needed to make a company tick. Quarterly goals are measured across all teams, which is also refreshing.

Upside – Doxmity has a really bright future, which is fantastic. But an even bigger upside is that employees get support to personally grow. I’ve seen many people get hired for one job and transition to a dream role they never new existed.
cons: It’s a face-paced environment that runs on a pretty lean team. I love it – Doximity is my dream company - but not everyone will. End of quarter gets stressful for everyone (though we always find a way to blow off steam.)
advice_to_mgmt: Keep hiring similar people who value teamwork over politics. Doximity has done a great job of retaining talented folks motivated to make our company better and who make me laugh every day. There’s passion to build a great product and fix real problems. I know it’s hard to keep that alive as we grow, but keep doing what you’re doing.

review_title: Stability of An Established Company + Culture of a Startup
pros:
This is a company that cares about its mission and its employees. Strong growth and very positive long-term prospects give it the stability of a more established company, but it has the culture and perks of a fun, young startup.

Management listens and responds to employee requests & ideas. Teams are collaborative and lack the hierarchy that tends to add red tape and aggravation at other companies. Goals are ambitious and productivity is rewarded.

Moreso than at any other place I've worked, employees genuinely like and respect each other. There are no jerks here. Also very few egos. People take their work seriously but don't take themselves seriously, which is a rare and amazing combo.

Doximity does a good job of "hiring slow and firing fast." Non-performers aren't given a chance to stick around and poison the well for the rest of us, which is hugely appreciated. Turnover is very low and those who work hard and perform well are able to rise quickly into leadership roles.

Jeff (CEO) is strategic, smart, and sincere. He has a proven track record and has helped Doximity avoid many of the typical startup pitfalls by putting his experience into proactive decisions for the good of the company. He is very approachable and is open with employees about company goals, prospects, and trajectory, which breeds a culture of honesty and openness. Employees trust and respect him, and he trusts and respects employees.
cons:
I honestly don't have any complaints about this company. When growing pains happen, they are very quickly remedied.
That said, Doximity is not for everyone. If you are someone who craves a corporate environment with many levels of management and corner offices, you probably won't be very happy here. Managers are quite hands on and work hard at Doximity (there are no "paper pushers" here). Our CEO sits in the open office floorplan with everyone else.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to trust employees and maintain a collaborative culture as we scale.

free snacks

review_title: Best company I've ever worked for
pros: Real and exciting product that meets the needs of physicians, constant innovations and exciting new products. Dynamic and engaged c-level leadership and board. Highest-quality people at every level. A "no a**hole" policy.
cons: Everyone is busy as hell, you will be too. But pay is competitive, you are contributing to something bigger than yourself, and there's a payoff at the end of the road.

pros: Overall the company is great. Nice perks; quarterly off-sites, free lunches, company bar. Good benefits.
cons: If you are planning on starting a family, don't expect any time off or remote work. Work over family.

review_title: Can be fun to work here but work from home policy is no good
pros: some great people work here, can be fun to get your job done. hard working environment with several specialists
cons:
work from home policy is garbage & unfair.

if you do not live near the office it is allowed - if you live near the office you are out of luck.
advice_to_mgmt: trust your employees & help them be more productive by allowing them to work remotely.

review_title: Easy to get a lot done
pros:
- The company is growing fast and there are a lot of talented people already
- Healthy culture where people are respectful and competent
- Strong products that have a lot of revenue potential
cons: - Sometimes people can be terse, strictly business then done
advice_to_mgmt: Offsites are over rated, give people bonuses instead

review_title: One of the best SF startups you've never heard of
pros: Great vision, leadership, and execution. Highly skilled & productive team. Fun culture. Very low turnover rate. The team is passionate about their products and responds quickly to client/user feedback.
cons: Benefits could be better, particularly PTO & WFH

pros: Building something unique in a niche space.
cons: No negatives to report, nothing at all.
advice_to_mgmt: N/A

pros: Employees are very dedicated and organised
cons: Lack of empathy towards employees

review_title: Great company, fast paced, lots of growth, and great potential
pros:
Quarterly offsites (Lake Tahoe, Punta Mita MX)
Mentorship and learning opportunities
cons: Would prefer more fringe benefits

review_title: A refreshing culture of getting the job done but having a great time while you do it
pros: Like most silicon valley start ups there are some great perks, catered lunch, great off-site meetings in places like Tahoe and Stinson. What sets Dox apart is the people, some of the best hard working people I've ever worked with, and unlike other jobs I've had there is no dead weight, which is refreshing.
cons: Not a tiny start up anymore but not yet a huge company - experiencing some growing pains as we "growup"
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work, keep hiring smart, allow dogs in the office :)

review_title: Sensible startup - Get to help doctors every day
pros:
- Many of the good things of classic startup culture (small teams, collaboration, mission-driven, casual, fun) without the drama and stress that can often be a trade off with young companies
- CEO has previously founded and led a health startup to IPO, has deep experience
- Super kind and friendly team
- Nice mission, work directly helps doctors all across the US
- Company is mature and stable far beyond its three years of history
cons:
- Office hours are very reasonable but people do take work home with them nights & weekends
- San Mateo location can be a commute challenge (company provides Caltrain passes)
- Odd mix of rugs in the office.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep focus on team culture as the company grows.

pros: The environment is very young, energetic, and passionate. Everyone is driven to ship as much code as quickly as possible, which really speeds up progress. The CEO is great at keeping the morale high. Culture is also still maintained, even though the company is growing really quickly. The perks are nice, especially the periodic off-sites, where everyone gets the chance to know each other on a more personal level.
cons: There's a certain level of pride/hubris that can be detected among the team, not that it's entirely undeserved. Also some politics and drama under the waters, but that's present at any company. They expect employees to be able to hit the ground running and won't waste too much time trying to train you if you can't pick things up very quickly.
